ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to do close reading and analyze queer modernist literature. I also learned interesting cultural context and history through these works, and how to become a better writer!
I learned how to do close readings and also a little bit about queer history
I learned a lot about queer writers and their works.
Very engaging and interesting course on queer modernist literature. Gained a background history on queer and modernist literature movements and close-text analysis critical thinking skills.

This course exposed me to a lot of important queer literature and ideas about how queerness was portrayed at a time when there were limited ways to describe it. The writing assignments helped me develop some close-reading skills.

This course was a fascinating look at some of the quintessential queer works of the early 20th century. In addition to learning about the books and gaining much historical context for the works, the class deepens student knowledge of how to close read texts.
Really interesting exposure to this period of LGBTQ+ history through the lens of literaturehow the history is reflected in the literature, and even, in some cases, how the literature impacted history
I learned how to close-read English works, especially through a queer lens. I also learned a lot about queer history.
Close reading

I learned all about queer history, the ways that the queer identity has developed, and been shaped and changed over long periods of time. I also learned about different ways literature portrayed queerness and queer life, and how such portrayal was received by the public. This course also taught  me a lot about individual authors of the books we read, and the  ways the literature they  wrote reflected events in their personal lives.
Constructions of queerness in modernist literature

A great understanding of queer literature and queer history before Stonewall. A comprehensive look at both the literature and the hardships the authors faced in terms of censorship and prosecution. A much deeper understanding of how the queer narrative has existed in literature through time.
I learned a lot about how queer people lived in the past and about literary elements.
I learned how to read efficiently and discuss the nuances and symbols within the books that we read in context with the time period they were written in.
Knowledge about queer history (especially in the 20th century), close reading skills
I learned about the significance of queer modernist literature and its social context.
learned a lot about queer history, how to do close readings, how to think about literary writing, and how to write academic essays.
I gained a much better understanding of what queer literature looked like pre-Stonewall, and how queer identities were shaped and conceptualized b the politics of their time.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Professor Richards is phenomenal, course curriculum and books were pretty cool too! Most of your interaction will be with your TF, who, for me, was also a strength because we always had fun discussions in section.
Weaknesses: This course is awesome, but I would've liked to see more non-white authors maybe.

Strengths - engaging lecturer who cares about their students

Weaknesses - class was super useless if you had not read the books since that is basically all we talked about. We were also expected to read approximately 1 book per week, so it was really easy to fall behind.

Strengths: The discussion section was helpful in discussing the texts, especially because the writing wasn't always the easiest thing to read. Professor Richards tried to keep lectures engaging with movie/video clips, which was really nice. My TA was really flexible with deadlines, and that was so nice with everything that's been going on. This also may have been just my TA, but feedback on returned papers is always a plus.

Weaknesses: This course wasn't really supportive of people who had never taken a college writing course before. More guidelines for those who had never analyzed a literary piece would have been appreciated. Recorded lectures would have been nice, but they won't be recorded for in-person so that's not necessarily a weakness. Also, just a side note, the books that are read in this class are generally not uplifting.
Strengths- very engaging lectures, powerpoints very effectively communicated important ideas/info

Strengths: Engaging and interesting content and readings
Cons: Readings were too long/fast-paced. Not enough time each week in section and in lecture to fully discuss the readings. Lectures often was on the background context or a specific close-text reading but rarely surrounded overall thematic ideas.
Prof. Richards is a great lecturer and the course was really engaging. Only weakness is I wish it was in person!

Strengths: Professor Richards is an awesome lecturer and has a really great, uplifting personality!
Weaknesses: Very heavy reading list, dont expect to read all of the novels especially if you are in any other reading-intense classes. Some of the books were dense or somewhat boring, also I felt too many were written by/about upper-class white people. The reading list could have used a little more variety in terms of represented voices

The reading list is something the professor is actively working on, but it is currently very aristocratic and white. You will be drained after reading about wealthy white Queer culture in Paris for the 6th book in a row. That being said, it does have some excellent reads and the professor and their lecturing is really great.

Strengths: We got to read seminal works in queer history, and Professor Richards' analysis is absolutely amazing to listen to. She was able to bring the works to life with her analysis, and I loved reading the books through that lens. Lectures were really fun and engaging. Weaknesses: I wish that we had learned more about actual queer history. I felt like a lot of the lectures were about close-reading certain passages, but I was missing some much-needed context. I also wish that we had read more books by authors of color. We barely touched on the Harlem Drag Balls and yet we spent so much time reading white authors who were blatantly racist (*cough cough* Virginia Woolf). I just wish that we had acknowledged more of the contributions of qtPOC because the course felt a bit alienating. I came in wanting to situate my own queerness within a historical context and instead found myself consistently alienated by the works we read.

Strengths: Professor Richards is so amazing!!  Her lectures are super engaging, relevant, and informative, and the way she closely read and engaged with the text during lectures really helped me understand how to close read novels and poetry in a way that was accessible and clear. The music they played every day before lecture also helped create a nice sense of community over the Zoom format. The accessibility of the teaching fellows  and the instructor was also key, and definitely made my experience in this class awesome. 

Weaknesses: I think some of the more challenging texts (e.g. Nightwood, Orlando) should have been introduced earlier on in the semester, and should also have been given more time to be  explored  and discussed in section and class. It also would have been nice to have read some more upbeat books that showed up happier/more positive queer futures.

Strengths: GREAT readings, fascinating lectures, and a sense of community among students despite the remote format. I also think the first close reading assignment was a great way to prepare us for the later papers. 
Weaknesses: We move a little too quickly through each reading, especially for dense texts like "Nightwood". I also think the final paper guidelines were a little restrictive. Each prompt required a a comparison of two texts from the second half of the syllabus (although different combinations were ultimately permitted). It made comparisons feel forced, where I would have preferred to write a paper that was more topic-driven and simply examined that topic through the lens of multiple texts.

I would have enjoyed a more engaging discussion section, but the lectures themselves were fantastic. The reading became overwhelming towards the end of the course with a new book due every week. The inclusion of queer history alongside the novels was my favorite part of the class.

I think the strongest aspect of the course is its  syllabus. Every book on the syllabus brings something new to the discussion of modernism. However, the lectures sometimes felt inconsequential. I didnt feel like I needed to go to the lectures in order to do well on assignments and in discussion.
Great syllabus (although a few I was not able to completely get through), lectures were very engaging
Great course, readings are all picked pretty well. Definitely will be great to take in person, Professor Richards is lovely.

The lectures were interesting but I felt that at times they could be hard to follow just because there was so much information to take in. I did appreciate Professor Richards' close readings and text analyses, though. Some of the books were also hard to engage with--either they ere very dense in vocabulary/literary techniques, or just weren't the most interesting.
this course was very informative and went along at a good pace. the professor was engaging and very knowledgeable.

(My above rating is mostly a result of stretching myself too thin this semester, rather than any facet of the class.)

Strengths: I loved the specificity of the paper prompts and the passages we looked at during section and lectures.

Weaknesses: I know that limiting book selection to pre-Stonewall makes this difficult, but I would have loved to talk more about how queer people were able to find happiness on or off the page and what that means for our discussions of queer futurity.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor was super understanding about extensions, attendance, etc.

During the virtual lectures, there were not many opportunities for engagement which was expected because it was a lecture course. However, the polling function on Zoom could have been used more to help the professor gain more insight on student opinion during the lecture. Overall though, the lectures were excellent and interesting and I enjoyed them greatly.
Every COVID accommodation was as successful as it could have been.

The use of video clips during lecture was very successful! The slides kept me consistently engaged. I do wish that more of the works that we read had been available to read online. I also wish that lectures were recorded so that we could go back and review anything we missed.
Jill Richards is a fantastic lecturer, even through zoom. She kept it entertaining and engaging, and I always loved logging on to this class.
This might be a small point but I loved the songs that would play at the beginning of every class. It really helped to get people into the mood while introducing students to good music.
Breakout rooms in the virtual lecture helped keep us engaged. Professor Richards is also lively and fun to listen to.

Break out rooms were not as successful as the professor believed them to be. I did enjoy the times we were encouraged to turn our cameras on and stretch or do other things on camera and engage with one another.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes!! Professor Richards is amazing at engaging students and creating a lively class, even during zoom times.
Yes! It's not too difficult and it's a fun writing credit if you want to learn more about queer fiction!!

This is a great English class for those who enjoy modernist literature, especially literature written by queer authors, and for those who might not be experts in close reading or writing literature papers. The structure of the assignments (shorter, mid-length, then longer paper) provided a gentle introduction to how to close reading, and then expanded upon those skills as the semester went on. Professor Richards provided examples in class of how they might close read certain passages, which was helpful for understanding what was expected in our papers.

I feel like this course was just a little bit misleading. I was expecting more of a history class where we learn about queer history through reading books but this got really English-y. Like a lot of close readings, examining art, etc. instead of learning about queer people and broadly how they lived. This just isn't what I expected - if you want to read old books that are queer/queercoded and analyze them, this is the class for you! If you are looking for more of a history class, however, then you should not take this.

I would recommend this course to those who are comfortable with modern literature and with reading a couple hundred pages a week. But it's not a hard course necessarily, so anyone interested should at least shop it.

yes- I took this course, unaware at first that it was an English course, and LOVED it!  The selected works that are read are very insightful pieces of queer literature, and the course is very entertaining.

Yes! Wide and great selection of queer modernist literature and taught with engaging lectures. However, do note that it is fast paced: often will be moving to a new or two new books every week which in turn leaves not a lot of time to get in depth with the material. Thus, some of the discussions often are surface level.

I would recommend this course to another student. I think that this is a great course in the English department that gives a good introduction into important queer literature while still being accessible to those that are not English majors. It is well organized and while there is a lot of reading, the reading list is interesting and varied. It was very enjoyable to go to lectures and be exposed to numerous ideas and perspectives about the books.
yes! really excellent readings and gossipy lectures
Absolutely! Amazing English course. Great works. Great lectures.

Yes! A great opportunity to get an exposure to LGBTQ+ history through the lens of a literature course. Be prepared for an intense reading list thoughdont expect to be able to read every page of every text

I would recommend this course to people looking to read seminal queer works and receive fabulous insight into these works during lecture. Just be aware that the works we read are unfortunately very white. I wouldn't take this course if you're expecting more historical insight.
Yes! Reading modernist literature through a queer lens is quite fascinating

Yes! This was a very interesting and eye-opening course to take. The different literary works that Professor Richards picked for this class provided a really varied, rich understanding  of queer literature, and the way so many different themes/concepts (e.g. colonial same-sex desire, the queer underworld, upper-class queer desire) have come out play over the course of history.
Yes! Truly amazing lectures and readings.
Yes. A great overview of queer literature and queer history. Somewhat heavy reading load, but really good books.
Yes, very fun and interesting. ALthough there is a lot of readings, the books vary and always teach a new story.
Yes. Its a great way to study queer literature and an interesting historical period.
Yes! Very interesting books + gained a much better understanding of 20th century queer history
I would recommend this course, the readings can be really interesting, and the modernist period is also just an important time period to understand.
Yes! This is a great course for a student looking to learn more about queer theory and literature in one.

NA

live section

The course included live virtual lectures and virtual discussion sections.
Weekly discussion section
